Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery band-cup; interior glazed black; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of five diving dolphins (of leftmost and fourth dolphins, face and tail missing, of fifth only part of belly preserved; all have traces of added white and added red on body); black below; ancient repair hole.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

For the motif of dolphins on the inside of the rim, compare the band cup from Naukratis in Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-G.137.38. The iconography is discussed by Eric Csapo, ‘The dolphins of Dionysos’ in E. Csapo and M. Miller (eds)Poetry, theory, praxis; the social life of myth, word and image in ancient Greece; essays in honour of William J. Slater, Oxford 2003, 78-90.
Bibliographic references: CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 42, pl. XXI, no. 22)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p.411, no. B630)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1374) (phase 3)
